title: 克劳迪奥·阿巴多、毛里奇奥·波利尼与安娜·普罗哈斯卡
short_description: 克劳迪奥·阿巴多与毛里奇奥·波利尼的艺术友谊是古典音乐界的一段佳话。在本场2011年的音乐会中，他们联手演绎了莫扎特的《第十七钢琴协奏曲》。女高音安娜·普罗哈斯卡是一位资深的莫扎特诠释者，她在本场音乐会中为我们带来了贝尔格的《璐璐》组曲。音乐会在马勒《第十交响曲》的柔板乐章中落下帷幕。

metadata.title: 克劳迪奥·阿巴多、毛里奇奥·波利尼与安娜·普罗哈斯卡
metadata.description: 克劳迪奥·阿巴多与毛里奇奥·波利尼的艺术友谊是古典音乐界的一段佳话。在本场2011年的音乐会中，他们联手演绎了莫扎特的《第十七钢琴协奏曲》。女高音安娜·普罗哈斯卡是一位资深的莫扎特诠释者，她在本场音乐会中为我们带来了贝尔格的《璐璐》组曲。音乐会在马勒《第十交响曲》的柔板乐章中落下帷幕。

concert.title: 克劳迪奥·阿巴多、毛里奇奥·波利尼与安娜·普罗哈斯卡

interview.title: 阿巴多、波利尼和普罗哈斯卡谈论新旧音乐友谊
interview.description: Claudio Abbado and Maurizio Pollini have been performing together for half a century: a unique friendship among artists that continues to reveal new facets. As happened in the middle of May 2011, when the two musicians performed their first joint interpretation of Mozart’s Piano Concerto No. 17 in G major. The evening also included other highlights: works by Berg and Mahler, and performances by the young soprano Anna Prohaska. Claudio Abbado, Maurizio Pollini and Anna Prohaska discuss the concert with Sarah Wills, horn player with the Berliner Philharmoniker.
interview.short_description: 2011年5月，克劳迪奥·阿巴多与毛里奇奥·波利尼、安娜·普罗哈斯卡合作了一场音乐会。在这里，柏林爱乐乐团的圆号演奏员莎拉·维利斯与他们进行了一场对话。
interview.caption:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:00,380

2
00:00:00,380 --> 00:00:03,480
Welcome to the Digital Concert
Hall, Anna Prohaska, Claudio

3
00:00:03,480 --> 00:00:05,250
Abbado, Maurizio Pollini.

4
00:00:05,250 --> 00:00:08,360
Thank you very much for taking
the time to talk to me.

5
00:00:08,360 --> 00:00:11,690
Claudio, this is like a week of
old friends new friends for

6
00:00:11,690 --> 00:00:12,620
you, isn't it?

7
00:00:12,620 --> 00:00:17,380
We have a new friend, Anna, and
an old friend, Maurizio,

8
00:00:17,380 --> 00:00:20,020
and old friends in the
orchestra as well.

9
00:00:20,020 --> 00:00:23,610
How does it feel to come back
and bring everyone together?

10
00:00:23,610 --> 00:00:27,385
It's always a great, great
pleasure to make music, to see

11
00:00:27,385 --> 00:00:29,390
all the friends again.

12
00:00:29,390 --> 00:00:31,590
Of course, with Maurizio
so many years.

13
00:00:31,590 --> 00:00:33,220
How many years do you
know each other?

14
00:00:33,220 --> 00:00:40,180
Almost a half century, and we
play so many concertos from

15
00:00:40,180 --> 00:00:44,360
Mozart, Nono, and Brahms,
Beethoven,

16
00:00:44,360 --> 00:00:46,200
all Beethoven's concertos.

17
00:00:46,200 --> 00:00:49,360
You've played everything, I
think, together that there is.

18
00:00:49,360 --> 00:00:51,350
We play many things.

19
00:00:51,350 --> 00:00:52,320
Not everything.

20
00:00:52,320 --> 00:00:53,160
Not everything.

21
00:00:53,160 --> 00:00:54,990
A good number of concertos.

22
00:00:54,990 --> 00:00:56,170
Quite a good collaboration.

23
00:00:56,170 --> 00:00:57,160
Absolutely, absolutely.

24
00:00:57,160 --> 00:00:59,880
But tonight's concerto is one
that you haven't played

25
00:00:59,880 --> 00:01:01,120
together, is that right?

26
00:01:01,120 --> 00:01:01,740
No.

27
00:01:01,740 --> 00:01:02,600
No, it's right.

28
00:01:02,600 --> 00:01:03,850
We haven't played together.

29
00:01:03,850 --> 00:01:06,430

30
00:01:06,430 --> 00:01:07,680
It's a marvelous concerto.

31
00:01:07,680 --> 00:01:10,060

32
00:01:10,060 --> 00:01:15,530
I didn't play it for a few
years, and hearing now these

33
00:01:15,530 --> 00:01:21,040
sounds, the marvelous sound of
Mozart so well played by the

34
00:01:21,040 --> 00:01:24,310
orchestra was really a great joy
for me, like a discovery.

35
00:01:24,310 --> 00:01:26,860
I really know very well
the concerto.

36
00:01:26,860 --> 00:01:33,130
It's one of those perhaps not
played so often, but it's one

37
00:01:33,130 --> 00:01:34,840
of the most beautiful
concertos by Mozart.

38
00:01:34,840 --> 00:01:39,100
Doesn't require a timpani
and trumpets.

39
00:01:39,100 --> 00:01:42,280
It's more a chamber concerto.

40
00:01:42,280 --> 00:01:46,890
But the invention is so
extraordinary, for instance,

41
00:01:46,890 --> 00:01:50,540
the invention of the third
movement, the variation.

42
00:01:50,540 --> 00:01:55,820
This is already going into the
line that Beethoven will

43
00:01:55,820 --> 00:01:57,610
follow later.

44
00:01:57,610 --> 00:02:01,420
It's an extraordinary way of
composing a variation.

45
00:02:01,420 --> 00:02:05,140
And the second movement with
all the modulation is

46
00:02:05,140 --> 00:02:09,770
absolutely magical, one of the
great movements of Mozart.

47
00:02:09,770 --> 00:02:13,180
There's quite a lot of light
and shade in this concerto.

48
00:02:13,180 --> 00:02:15,680
It starts so happy, and then
all of a sudden, it gets a

49
00:02:15,680 --> 00:02:18,660
little bit shadowy.

50
00:02:18,660 --> 00:02:21,760
It is basically a
happy concerto,

51
00:02:21,760 --> 00:02:23,690
but it has also shadows.

52
00:02:23,690 --> 00:02:26,370
Can you two remember the first
time you played together?

53
00:02:26,370 --> 00:02:29,650

54
00:02:29,650 --> 00:02:30,840
Chopin?

55
00:02:30,840 --> 00:02:35,110
Chopin concerto in Italy
in the '60s.

56
00:02:35,110 --> 00:02:35,740
In the '60s.

57
00:02:35,740 --> 00:02:38,930
Can you remember the first time
you played with Anna?

58
00:02:38,930 --> 00:02:40,456
It's not so long ago, is it?

59
00:02:40,456 --> 00:02:43,120
The first time was with Lulu.

60
00:02:43,120 --> 00:02:43,530
Mm-hm.

61
00:02:43,530 --> 00:02:44,680
In Caracas.

62
00:02:44,680 --> 00:02:45,420
In Venezuela.

63
00:02:45,420 --> 00:02:47,120
Ooh, that's a nice place
for a [INAUDIBLE].

64
00:02:47,120 --> 00:02:49,517
Yeah, with Simon Bolivar
Orchestra, with Abreu.

65
00:02:49,517 --> 00:02:50,311
Fantastic.

66
00:02:50,311 --> 00:02:52,850
And, I believe, Anna and
Maurizio, you'll be playing

67
00:02:52,850 --> 00:02:54,860
together for the first
time soon, no?

68
00:02:54,860 --> 00:02:56,010
In Lucerne?

69
00:02:56,010 --> 00:03:01,760
Yes, in the summer, at the
Lucerne Festival, because Anna

70
00:03:01,760 --> 00:03:05,880
will sing a new work by Giacomo
Manzoni, the Italian

71
00:03:05,880 --> 00:03:12,770
composer, a new work that will
have its premiere in Lucerne.

72
00:03:12,770 --> 00:03:17,820
And so I'm very happy that
you accepted to do that.

73
00:03:17,820 --> 00:03:18,410
Oh yes.

74
00:03:18,410 --> 00:03:20,310
I'm also very, very honest.

75
00:03:20,310 --> 00:03:25,980
I met Giacomo Manzoni in the
evening for Claudio's 75th

76
00:03:25,980 --> 00:03:30,860
birthday concert and Giacomo
decided to write

77
00:03:30,860 --> 00:03:31,780
something for me.

78
00:03:31,780 --> 00:03:36,110
And it's such a great honor that
it will be together with

79
00:03:36,110 --> 00:03:39,010
these wonderful gentlemen in
this amazing festival, and

80
00:03:39,010 --> 00:03:42,290
we're going to take it all over
the world, so to Paris,

81
00:03:42,290 --> 00:03:44,250
to New York, to Berlin.

82
00:03:44,250 --> 00:03:45,400
Fantastic.

83
00:03:45,400 --> 00:03:45,880
I didn't know.

84
00:03:45,880 --> 00:03:48,810
You didn't know?

85
00:03:48,810 --> 00:03:51,050
That's when you heard Anna for
the first time, on the

86
00:03:51,050 --> 00:03:52,680
recording of the Rihm
piece that was

87
00:03:52,680 --> 00:03:53,630
written for your birthday.

88
00:03:53,630 --> 00:03:54,310
Do you remember?

89
00:03:54,310 --> 00:03:55,380
Yeah, exactly.

90
00:03:55,380 --> 00:03:58,240
And what did you think when
you heard this voice?

91
00:03:58,240 --> 00:04:02,950
Yes, that's a personality,
fantastic.

92
00:04:02,950 --> 00:04:05,980
And also, we work together,
we understand

93
00:04:05,980 --> 00:04:07,270
each other very well.

94
00:04:07,270 --> 00:04:08,540
You said that to me
the other day.

95
00:04:08,540 --> 00:04:12,230
You said when you worked on the
Mozart with Anna, you said

96
00:04:12,230 --> 00:04:15,460
you just understood each other
from the first notes.

97
00:04:15,460 --> 00:04:17,110
Isn't that wonderful
when that happens?

98
00:04:17,110 --> 00:04:17,959
Yes.

99
00:04:17,959 --> 00:04:21,589
When you have somebody
who can make music,

100
00:04:21,589 --> 00:04:24,916
great music, and [ITALIAN].

101
00:04:24,916 --> 00:04:27,520
You two have this as well, but
for a little bit longer.

102
00:04:27,520 --> 00:04:29,026
Yeah.

103
00:04:29,026 --> 00:04:30,750
Do you have a favorite concerto

104
00:04:30,750 --> 00:04:32,750
you like to do together?

105
00:04:32,750 --> 00:04:36,780
We play all the Beethoven,
all the Brahms.

106
00:04:36,780 --> 00:04:41,340
It's very difficult to
choose one concerto.

107
00:04:41,340 --> 00:04:42,790
You like them all.

108
00:04:42,790 --> 00:04:44,260
It's like when someone says,
what's your favorite composer?

109
00:04:44,260 --> 00:04:46,940
And I always think, depends
on the mood.

110
00:04:46,940 --> 00:04:48,180
Impossible question.

111
00:04:48,180 --> 00:04:49,770
Impossible, yes.

112
00:04:49,770 --> 00:04:53,210
But you must have had some
great tours in your time.

113
00:04:53,210 --> 00:04:54,450
What you do when you're
not playing?

114
00:04:54,450 --> 00:04:55,630
What do you do after
the concert?

115
00:04:55,630 --> 00:04:58,790
You go out and eat great
Italian food?

116
00:04:58,790 --> 00:04:59,470
Sometimes.

117
00:04:59,470 --> 00:04:59,730
Sometimes--

118
00:04:59,730 --> 00:04:59,850
Why not?

119
00:04:59,850 --> 00:05:00,450
--it's possible.

120
00:05:00,450 --> 00:05:02,550
Sometimes it's not possible.

121
00:05:02,550 --> 00:05:10,800
In holiday times when
many things going to

122
00:05:10,800 --> 00:05:12,135
the sea, for instance.

123
00:05:12,135 --> 00:05:13,960
Some musicians don't like
to have holidays.

124
00:05:13,960 --> 00:05:17,160
Some musicians just like
to work, work, work.

125
00:05:17,160 --> 00:05:24,170
Or visiting towns and cities
and monuments, or

126
00:05:24,170 --> 00:05:26,650
being in the theater.

127
00:05:26,650 --> 00:05:27,880
There are many, many things.

128
00:05:27,880 --> 00:05:29,010
Or being with friends.

129
00:05:29,010 --> 00:05:31,310
Claudio, you like
to cook, right?

130
00:05:31,310 --> 00:05:32,100
Yes.

131
00:05:32,100 --> 00:05:34,906
We see each other sometimes
in Sardinia

132
00:05:34,906 --> 00:05:36,190
or up in the mountains.

133
00:05:36,190 --> 00:05:38,080
Make holidays together.

134
00:05:38,080 --> 00:05:39,530
I don't know if we
make holidays, or

135
00:05:39,530 --> 00:05:40,640
sometimes we prepare.

136
00:05:40,640 --> 00:05:43,600
I remember when we prepared the
Beethoven Piano Concerto

137
00:05:43,600 --> 00:05:46,305
for Berlin, that we were
working in [INAUDIBLE].

138
00:05:46,305 --> 00:05:48,685
You did a lot together here
in Berlin, didn't you?

139
00:05:48,685 --> 00:05:49,000
Yeah.

140
00:05:49,000 --> 00:05:51,430
Is it one of your favorite
orchestras to work with?

141
00:05:51,430 --> 00:05:52,680
I hope you say yes.

142
00:05:52,680 --> 00:05:55,200

143
00:05:55,200 --> 00:05:56,320
It's one of the--

144
00:05:56,320 --> 00:05:56,720
Logical.

145
00:05:56,720 --> 00:05:59,730
It's a logical answer, but
it's absolutely true.

146
00:05:59,730 --> 00:06:01,530
And do you miss it, Claudio?

147
00:06:01,530 --> 00:06:01,620
Sorry?

148
00:06:01,620 --> 00:06:03,320
Do you miss the orchestra?

149
00:06:03,320 --> 00:06:04,510
No, I don't miss it.

150
00:06:04,510 --> 00:06:05,410
I come every year.

151
00:06:05,410 --> 00:06:05,890
You come every year.

152
00:06:05,890 --> 00:06:07,460
We don't give you a
chance to miss us.

153
00:06:07,460 --> 00:06:08,550
No, but you know how it is.

154
00:06:08,550 --> 00:06:11,235
I play just one concert in
Berlin, two concerts in

155
00:06:11,235 --> 00:06:13,725
Lucerne, and something with
a Mozart Orchestra.

156
00:06:13,725 --> 00:06:14,780
That's it.

157
00:06:14,780 --> 00:06:15,600
But you're feeling fine?

158
00:06:15,600 --> 00:06:16,190
Yeah.

159
00:06:16,190 --> 00:06:16,845
Great.

160
00:06:16,845 --> 00:06:20,090
But I take more time
for myself to

161
00:06:20,090 --> 00:06:23,570
study, to read, to learn.

162
00:06:23,570 --> 00:06:25,200
All life, we have to
learn something.

163
00:06:25,200 --> 00:06:25,970
It's important.

164
00:06:25,970 --> 00:06:29,130
Anna, you're still so young and
vivacious, you don't need

165
00:06:29,130 --> 00:06:31,600
to take so much time for
yourself, or do you?

166
00:06:31,600 --> 00:06:34,120
What you do when you're not
preparing, because you're

167
00:06:34,120 --> 00:06:35,590
quite busy these days?

168
00:06:35,590 --> 00:06:37,230
Definitely.

169
00:06:37,230 --> 00:06:40,620
Sometimes maybe once a year, I
have a three week holiday, and

170
00:06:40,620 --> 00:06:43,480
otherwise I'm usually
working through.

171
00:06:43,480 --> 00:06:46,790
If I have three, four five days
sometime, I love to just

172
00:06:46,790 --> 00:06:49,980
go off, take a plane to some new
city that I haven't seen.

173
00:06:49,980 --> 00:06:51,790
I'm not so much of
a beach person.

174
00:06:51,790 --> 00:06:55,880
I love to go to a new place to
see, for example, historical

175
00:06:55,880 --> 00:06:58,930
excavations, wonderful
museums.

176
00:06:58,930 --> 00:07:01,620
Those are the things that I do
first in a new town, and then

177
00:07:01,620 --> 00:07:04,160
I like to hear the local
orchestra, see

178
00:07:04,160 --> 00:07:05,800
maybe a play in a theater.

179
00:07:05,800 --> 00:07:08,740
I'm a great fan of straight
theater as well, so not just

180
00:07:08,740 --> 00:07:12,040
music, but also theater
in the wider sense.

181
00:07:12,040 --> 00:07:14,030
I'm a huge history fan.

182
00:07:14,030 --> 00:07:17,490
I love to read about the
Roman Empire up to the

183
00:07:17,490 --> 00:07:19,780
Second World War.

184
00:07:19,780 --> 00:07:22,090
That's one of the most
interesting things for me.

185
00:07:22,090 --> 00:07:24,995
And I love hiking, so I'm
from the mountains.

186
00:07:24,995 --> 00:07:26,630
Well, you'll have to
go together, then.

187
00:07:26,630 --> 00:07:27,070
Yeah.

188
00:07:27,070 --> 00:07:28,160
Yeah, why not?

189
00:07:28,160 --> 00:07:31,840
We went on a little hike in
Venezuela in the botanical

190
00:07:31,840 --> 00:07:35,080
gardens that have quite a
lot of hills and stuff,

191
00:07:35,080 --> 00:07:36,490
and it was very hot.

192
00:07:36,490 --> 00:07:37,370
I remember that.

193
00:07:37,370 --> 00:07:40,578
It was very humid and hot.

194
00:07:40,578 --> 00:07:41,522
I forgot.

195
00:07:41,522 --> 00:07:44,010
Anna, I know, she's very sporty,
and when she goes

196
00:07:44,010 --> 00:07:48,000
jogging, she likes to listen to
heavy metal, so it's quite

197
00:07:48,000 --> 00:07:49,750
incredible, heavy metal music.

198
00:07:49,750 --> 00:07:53,370
So this incredibly ethereal
voice, and while she's

199
00:07:53,370 --> 00:07:55,090
jogging, she hears
heavy metal.

200
00:07:55,090 --> 00:07:57,640
Do you have any secret
music loves as well?

201
00:07:57,640 --> 00:08:00,350
When I was sick, I heard Bach.

202
00:08:00,350 --> 00:08:03,840
It was a great medicine.

203
00:08:03,840 --> 00:08:04,782
Medicine, yeah.

204
00:08:04,782 --> 00:08:06,670
Bach is good medicine.

205
00:08:06,670 --> 00:08:09,490
Medicine for the soul,
isn't it, music?

206
00:08:09,490 --> 00:08:12,490
Are you a jazz fan, or
do you like other

207
00:08:12,490 --> 00:08:14,220
types of music as well?

208
00:08:14,220 --> 00:08:16,730
I was a jazz fan when
I was very, very

209
00:08:16,730 --> 00:08:19,570
young, 16 years old.

210
00:08:19,570 --> 00:08:23,230
But after this period, not
so much, absolutely.

211
00:08:23,230 --> 00:08:25,530
You're for Mozart.

212
00:08:25,530 --> 00:08:26,830
Yes, you can hear it.

213
00:08:26,830 --> 00:08:28,650
It's really so wonderful
to hear you

214
00:08:28,650 --> 00:08:30,080
playing Mozart this week.

215
00:08:30,080 --> 00:08:31,600
The program, Claudio.

216
00:08:31,600 --> 00:08:35,780
Tell me, you've balanced Mozart
and then Berg, and then

217
00:08:35,780 --> 00:08:37,470
Mozart and then Mahler.

218
00:08:37,470 --> 00:08:40,929
And the Mahler 10, I couldn't
find any information that

219
00:08:40,929 --> 00:08:43,510
you've done this before in the
orchestra because you did a

220
00:08:43,510 --> 00:08:46,010
lot of Mahler with the
Philharmonic because they

221
00:08:46,010 --> 00:08:47,430
didn't play so much
Mahler, did they?

222
00:08:47,430 --> 00:08:49,860
We played all the symphonies,
I think.

223
00:08:49,860 --> 00:08:50,970
All of them.

224
00:08:50,970 --> 00:08:55,310
Except the 8, that
we didn't play.

225
00:08:55,310 --> 00:08:56,060
You--

226
00:08:56,060 --> 00:08:57,320
I recorded.

227
00:08:57,320 --> 00:08:58,340
You did the 8.

228
00:08:58,340 --> 00:09:00,180
I remember.

229
00:09:00,180 --> 00:09:00,765
You were here--

230
00:09:00,765 --> 00:09:01,450
In Berlin?

231
00:09:01,450 --> 00:09:02,302
In Berlin.

232
00:09:02,302 --> 00:09:04,024
Then he's right.

233
00:09:04,024 --> 00:09:04,516
Yes?

234
00:09:04,516 --> 00:09:07,470
See, friends know you best.

235
00:09:07,470 --> 00:09:11,540
This aria that Anna's singing,
yesterday in the rehearsal, we

236
00:09:11,540 --> 00:09:15,550
were all just smiling during
it because it's incredibly

237
00:09:15,550 --> 00:09:17,055
difficult, incredibly
virtuosic,

238
00:09:17,055 --> 00:09:18,800
and absolutely gorgeous.

239
00:09:18,800 --> 00:09:19,200
Yes.

240
00:09:19,200 --> 00:09:20,690
She's doing wonderful.

241
00:09:20,690 --> 00:09:22,410
Is it particularly difficult
to sing?

242
00:09:22,410 --> 00:09:23,280
Well, yes.

243
00:09:23,280 --> 00:09:26,460
I mean, you've got to really
hold yourself back and

244
00:09:26,460 --> 00:09:29,400
constantly, you think about
technique, although I'm more

245
00:09:29,400 --> 00:09:30,490
of an emotional person.

246
00:09:30,490 --> 00:09:34,450
I'm someone who accesses music
through emotions, and also

247
00:09:34,450 --> 00:09:37,890
through the brain, thinking
about the text, of course, but

248
00:09:37,890 --> 00:09:40,550
especially through feeling
the music.

249
00:09:40,550 --> 00:09:44,630
And if you let your body go wild
during the piece, then

250
00:09:44,630 --> 00:09:48,490
you lose this amazing, pristine,
crystalline line

251
00:09:48,490 --> 00:09:52,640
which you have to have for this
very slow and very high

252
00:09:52,640 --> 00:09:55,660
and languid sounding Mozart.

253
00:09:55,660 --> 00:09:59,110
So it's a bit of a challenge,
but with this amazing

254
00:09:59,110 --> 00:10:02,940
accompaniment, it's not
as difficult as I

255
00:10:02,940 --> 00:10:03,912
thought it would be.

256
00:10:03,912 --> 00:10:07,775
It was wonderful to hear the
voice, and then with the oboe,

257
00:10:07,775 --> 00:10:08,510
[INAUDIBLE].

258
00:10:08,510 --> 00:10:10,090
That was a fantastic duet.

259
00:10:10,090 --> 00:10:10,775
It is.

260
00:10:10,775 --> 00:10:12,180
It's like two voices together.

261
00:10:12,180 --> 00:10:12,750
It's wonderful.

262
00:10:12,750 --> 00:10:16,500
That's what I love about also
being in a duet with an oboe

263
00:10:16,500 --> 00:10:19,620
because it's maybe the
instrument that's closest to

264
00:10:19,620 --> 00:10:21,270
the soprano voice.

265
00:10:21,270 --> 00:10:25,530
It's practically the same
tessitura, and it's also got a

266
00:10:25,530 --> 00:10:28,550
similar sound with the vibrato,
the non-vibrato,

267
00:10:28,550 --> 00:10:30,810
these things that they
can also play with.

268
00:10:30,810 --> 00:10:33,980
And also, I have a kind of
double reed in my throat,

269
00:10:33,980 --> 00:10:35,580
haven't I, like a double
reed instrument?

270
00:10:35,580 --> 00:10:37,020
A double reed in your throat.

271
00:10:37,020 --> 00:10:38,960
Physically, it's a
similar thing.

272
00:10:38,960 --> 00:10:41,060
It's really true.

273
00:10:41,060 --> 00:10:43,950
Is it particularly nerve
wracking as a young singer to

274
00:10:43,950 --> 00:10:46,250
get up on stage and
[INAUDIBLE]?

275
00:10:46,250 --> 00:10:48,705
She has to start with Mozart.

276
00:10:48,705 --> 00:10:51,140
Yeah, to also start
with Mozart.

277
00:10:51,140 --> 00:10:53,160
It's quite a scary piece
to start with.

278
00:10:53,160 --> 00:10:53,410
That's true.

279
00:10:53,410 --> 00:10:54,080
It's a great piece.

280
00:10:54,080 --> 00:10:54,650
But it's better.

281
00:10:54,650 --> 00:10:56,670
Also, we start the
rehearsals too.

282
00:10:56,670 --> 00:10:57,800
Yeah.

283
00:10:57,800 --> 00:11:01,280
I find it better that way
because throughout the

284
00:11:01,280 --> 00:11:05,040
evening, I can get more
and more dramatic.

285
00:11:05,040 --> 00:11:10,480
So the first half of the aria is
very crystalline, and then

286
00:11:10,480 --> 00:11:14,170
it goes into more of a
spinto, more dramatic

287
00:11:14,170 --> 00:11:15,180
coloring in the Mozart.

288
00:11:15,180 --> 00:11:19,770
And then the next piece in the
Berg, which lets me really let

289
00:11:19,770 --> 00:11:24,830
rip, and I can really have fun
with the high notes and the

290
00:11:24,830 --> 00:11:25,740
coloratura.

291
00:11:25,740 --> 00:11:27,500
But it's a lot more dramatic.

292
00:11:27,500 --> 00:11:31,100
So technically, for the voice,
it's better that way to do

293
00:11:31,100 --> 00:11:35,540
Mozart first, and then a
romantic piece-- which I think

294
00:11:35,540 --> 00:11:36,370
Lulu still is.

295
00:11:36,370 --> 00:11:38,890
It's very late romantic.

296
00:11:38,890 --> 00:11:42,780
I've imagined with soloists,
when I've done horn concertos,

297
00:11:42,780 --> 00:11:46,060
the waiting is the worst part,
the traditional waiting until

298
00:11:46,060 --> 00:11:48,020
the overture is finished and
sitting in your dressing room

299
00:11:48,020 --> 00:11:49,170
all by yourself.

300
00:11:49,170 --> 00:11:52,022
Is that the worst part
for you, the waiting?

301
00:11:52,022 --> 00:11:53,760
It depends from the night.

302
00:11:53,760 --> 00:11:55,150
From the night, yeah.

303
00:11:55,150 --> 00:11:57,230
It's always a matter
of how you feel.

304
00:11:57,230 --> 00:11:59,630
This getting nervous thing
is never something

305
00:11:59,630 --> 00:12:01,030
I've managed to--

306
00:12:01,030 --> 00:12:02,710
And it doesn't get
less and less.

307
00:12:02,710 --> 00:12:03,290
I mean, you can--

308
00:12:03,290 --> 00:12:03,610
I don't know.

309
00:12:03,610 --> 00:12:04,590
Does it get less?

310
00:12:04,590 --> 00:12:06,080
Does getting nervous get less?

311
00:12:06,080 --> 00:12:07,540
I have the impression
that it stays.

312
00:12:07,540 --> 00:12:08,010
It stays.

313
00:12:08,010 --> 00:12:08,930
Oh no.

314
00:12:08,930 --> 00:12:11,090
We want it to go away.

315
00:12:11,090 --> 00:12:16,350
To be honest, singing my first
solo in [INAUDIBLE], or Haydn

316
00:12:16,350 --> 00:12:20,530
Mass or something in church or
at school was actually just as

317
00:12:20,530 --> 00:12:23,540
nerve wracking as performing
nowadays.

318
00:12:23,540 --> 00:12:26,850
It's just that nowadays, you
also know the consequences.

319
00:12:26,850 --> 00:12:31,570
You know the prospects, what
might happen, and you have

320
00:12:31,570 --> 00:12:33,920
much more of an idea of
the music industry and

321
00:12:33,920 --> 00:12:34,720
these kind of things.

322
00:12:34,720 --> 00:12:40,330
Also modern music industry with
all these electronic new

323
00:12:40,330 --> 00:12:44,140
introductions, like YouTube and
these things where we're

324
00:12:44,140 --> 00:12:48,350
constantly under surveillance
by the public.

325
00:12:48,350 --> 00:12:50,410
It's a lot more, I think,
than it was earlier.

326
00:12:50,410 --> 00:12:53,620
Now everybody can come with a
little camera, can record any

327
00:12:53,620 --> 00:12:56,150
rehearsal or any concert, and
then it's on the internet.

328
00:12:56,150 --> 00:12:56,600
What do you think of this?

329
00:12:56,600 --> 00:12:57,970
Do you agree with Anna?

330
00:12:57,970 --> 00:13:02,360
Everything is so recorded these
days, every little cough

331
00:13:02,360 --> 00:13:06,070
on stage, somebody's out
there recording it.

332
00:13:06,070 --> 00:13:11,640
In the future, there will be
witness of all musicians and

333
00:13:11,640 --> 00:13:15,590
nothing will escape, but it
will be a great help also.

334
00:13:15,590 --> 00:13:20,120
If we could know something
about Beethoven or Chopin

335
00:13:20,120 --> 00:13:24,780
playing, it would be a great
advantage for us, but we

336
00:13:24,780 --> 00:13:25,995
cannot have that.

337
00:13:25,995 --> 00:13:26,400
Absolutely.

338
00:13:26,400 --> 00:13:27,260
My brother's a conductor.

339
00:13:27,260 --> 00:13:29,960
But we have Stravinsky
conducting, and Schoenberg

340
00:13:29,960 --> 00:13:34,520
conducting, and other great
conductors, et cetera.

341
00:13:34,520 --> 00:13:37,460
You do this wonderful Progetto
Pollini, this wonderful

342
00:13:37,460 --> 00:13:39,600
mixture of old and new.

343
00:13:39,600 --> 00:13:44,655
You did Monteverdi was mixed
with Rihm and Boulez.

344
00:13:44,655 --> 00:13:51,040
I took care of some cycle of
concerts here, and they are

345
00:13:51,040 --> 00:13:54,340
also presenting some works that
are not played every day.

346
00:13:54,340 --> 00:13:59,180
And so also ancient work, as
well as some contemporary or

347
00:13:59,180 --> 00:14:07,910
modern works that are not, in
my opinion, played enough in

348
00:14:07,910 --> 00:14:15,210
the concert scene, which is
represented mostly by the 19th

349
00:14:15,210 --> 00:14:17,280
and 18th century.

350
00:14:17,280 --> 00:14:19,580
Nono was a great friend
of yours, wasn't he?

351
00:14:19,580 --> 00:14:20,100
Yes.

352
00:14:20,100 --> 00:14:21,760
I was reading about
the film that you

353
00:14:21,760 --> 00:14:22,960
made with him together.

354
00:14:22,960 --> 00:14:24,750
We played many--

355
00:14:24,750 --> 00:14:25,475
Many things.

356
00:14:25,475 --> 00:14:28,120
Many things for the
first time.

357
00:14:28,120 --> 00:14:30,390
Anna sang an opera by Nono.

358
00:14:30,390 --> 00:14:33,760
Al Gran Sole Carico D'Amore two
years ago at the Salzburg

359
00:14:33,760 --> 00:14:37,780
Festival, and I was so excited
to hear that Claudio did the

360
00:14:37,780 --> 00:14:40,490
world premiere at La
Scala back then.

361
00:14:40,490 --> 00:14:44,515
And a very turbulent time,
wasn't it, 1968 or around

362
00:14:44,515 --> 00:14:45,180
then? '68, '69?

363
00:14:45,180 --> 00:14:47,130
Yes, it was like a revolution.

364
00:14:47,130 --> 00:14:48,145
Yeah, yeah, yeah.

365
00:14:48,145 --> 00:14:49,235
With the audience of
La Scala, you know?

366
00:14:49,235 --> 00:14:50,710
I can imagine.

367
00:14:50,710 --> 00:14:52,840
How did they react to that?

368
00:14:52,840 --> 00:14:55,670
Somebody likes it, somebody
didn't like.

369
00:14:55,670 --> 00:14:57,760
But usually the ones who
don't like it are the

370
00:14:57,760 --> 00:14:58,650
louder ones, right?

371
00:14:58,650 --> 00:15:01,350
In La Scala, I think so, yeah.

372
00:15:01,350 --> 00:15:02,190
Not so much.

373
00:15:02,190 --> 00:15:03,090
No?

374
00:15:03,090 --> 00:15:04,570
No, not so much.

375
00:15:04,570 --> 00:15:06,860
But you know, it takes time.

376
00:15:06,860 --> 00:15:10,050
Like today we were just
talking about Mahler.

377
00:15:10,050 --> 00:15:14,140
When they played for the first
time Mahler 10, the adagio,

378
00:15:14,140 --> 00:15:16,210
they didn't understand
anything.

379
00:15:16,210 --> 00:15:17,590
It takes time.

380
00:15:17,590 --> 00:15:18,620
Mahler, [INAUDIBLE]

381
00:15:18,620 --> 00:15:21,720
we need a half century to
understand his music.

382
00:15:21,720 --> 00:15:23,440
And with Nono, it's the same.

383
00:15:23,440 --> 00:15:26,740
Do you think there's a
similarity between Mahler's

384
00:15:26,740 --> 00:15:29,760
10th Adagio and the Lulu Adagio,
because listening to

385
00:15:29,760 --> 00:15:32,950
both of them yesterday in the
rehearsal, there's very, very

386
00:15:32,950 --> 00:15:35,625
similar parts in there.

387
00:15:35,625 --> 00:15:38,310
You know, studying these two
scores, I was thinking, you

388
00:15:38,310 --> 00:15:41,120
know, Mahler was even more
modern than Berg.

389
00:15:41,120 --> 00:15:41,660
He was.

390
00:15:41,660 --> 00:15:42,800
With the harmony.

391
00:15:42,800 --> 00:15:45,650
There's something incredible.

392
00:15:45,650 --> 00:15:51,090
Of course, Berg is a wonderful
composer, so new

393
00:15:51,090 --> 00:15:53,210
for his time, no?

394
00:15:53,210 --> 00:15:56,820
But Mahler was at the beginning
of the 19th century,

395
00:15:56,820 --> 00:15:58,704
so that's incredible.

396
00:15:58,704 --> 00:16:00,120
So how about a Lulu with Anna?

397
00:16:00,120 --> 00:16:02,380
I can imagine you as
the perfect Lulu.

398
00:16:02,380 --> 00:16:03,360
Oh, thank you.

399
00:16:03,360 --> 00:16:04,196
I could.

400
00:16:04,196 --> 00:16:04,890
Don't you think?

401
00:16:04,890 --> 00:16:05,740
Yes, sure.

402
00:16:05,740 --> 00:16:06,530
So there we go.

403
00:16:06,530 --> 00:16:06,910
That's a collaboration.

404
00:16:06,910 --> 00:16:09,590
It was a project.

405
00:16:09,590 --> 00:16:11,480
You are doing it, I hope?

406
00:16:11,480 --> 00:16:13,910
Yeah, but I think in
a few years time.

407
00:16:13,910 --> 00:16:14,730
Not yet.

408
00:16:14,730 --> 00:16:18,130
As we all know, the orchestra
is just so huge, and the

409
00:16:18,130 --> 00:16:21,220
tessitura is actually for a
coloratura soprano, and you

410
00:16:21,220 --> 00:16:23,220
need a lot of middle, though.

411
00:16:23,220 --> 00:16:24,330
You need three voices.

412
00:16:24,330 --> 00:16:27,620
It's like Traviata, these
big, big soprano

413
00:16:27,620 --> 00:16:28,560
roles that you have.

414
00:16:28,560 --> 00:16:29,320
Yeah, very dramatic.

415
00:16:29,320 --> 00:16:31,040
Exactly, but also high.

416
00:16:31,040 --> 00:16:33,590
So I think I'll wait a
few years and then

417
00:16:33,590 --> 00:16:34,680
I'll be very happy.

418
00:16:34,680 --> 00:16:36,000
It's my absolute dream role.

419
00:16:36,000 --> 00:16:36,762
That's wise.

420
00:16:36,762 --> 00:16:38,570
Yeah.

421
00:16:38,570 --> 00:16:43,390
Claudio, we're up here in the
orchestra recreation room, and

422
00:16:43,390 --> 00:16:45,170
there's a poster here
on the wall--

423
00:16:45,170 --> 00:16:46,613
I don't know if you've
seen it-- from 1956,

424
00:16:46,613 --> 00:16:48,650
if I may say that.

425
00:16:48,650 --> 00:16:53,470
And it was a competition of
Carlo "Secchi," it says?

426
00:16:53,470 --> 00:16:54,260
Zecchi.

427
00:16:54,260 --> 00:16:55,610
Zecchi.

428
00:16:55,610 --> 00:16:57,750
And you were taking
part with Zubin

429
00:16:57,750 --> 00:16:59,440
Mehtca and Daniel Baremboim.

430
00:16:59,440 --> 00:16:59,860
Yeah, in Sienna.

431
00:16:59,860 --> 00:17:00,370
Do you remember this?

432
00:17:00,370 --> 00:17:00,950
In Sienna.

433
00:17:00,950 --> 00:17:01,630
It's on the poster.

434
00:17:01,630 --> 00:17:02,350
Yes, I remember this.

435
00:17:02,350 --> 00:17:04,869
And this is the original
poster from there.

436
00:17:04,869 --> 00:17:07,829
I didn't see the poster, but
I remember in Sienna.

437
00:17:07,829 --> 00:17:10,040
Yes, we're very privileged
to have this poster here.

438
00:17:10,040 --> 00:17:13,240
And Zecchi was a
great pianist.

439
00:17:13,240 --> 00:17:16,270
Then he decided to conduct,
and was teaching.

440
00:17:16,270 --> 00:17:17,859
It was very interesting.

441
00:17:17,859 --> 00:17:19,550
And who won?

442
00:17:19,550 --> 00:17:20,109
Who won?

443
00:17:20,109 --> 00:17:20,690
Who won the competition?

444
00:17:20,690 --> 00:17:21,079
Was it a competition?

445
00:17:21,079 --> 00:17:22,025
It was not a competition.

446
00:17:22,025 --> 00:17:24,700
Oh, it was just a concert of
all the up and coming young

447
00:17:24,700 --> 00:17:26,020
conductors.

448
00:17:26,020 --> 00:17:30,130
No, I think they invited
only a few conductors

449
00:17:30,130 --> 00:17:32,450
to study with Zecchi.

450
00:17:32,450 --> 00:17:33,110
We never knew this.

451
00:17:33,110 --> 00:17:34,540
It was not a competition.

452
00:17:34,540 --> 00:17:36,590
We though it was some sort
of a competition.

453
00:17:36,590 --> 00:17:38,380
It was a good friendship.

454
00:17:38,380 --> 00:17:40,570
Yeah, a good friendship.

455
00:17:40,570 --> 00:17:43,230
A good friendship like
all three of you, and

456
00:17:43,230 --> 00:17:44,020
thank you so much.

457
00:17:44,020 --> 00:17:44,940
You've been fantastic.

458
00:17:44,940 --> 00:17:45,490
Thank you.

459
00:17:45,490 --> 00:17:46,000
Thank you for coming
to talk to me.

460
00:17:46,000 --> 00:17:46,290
Thank you.

461
00:17:46,290 --> 00:17:47,400
You're a wonderful
host, Sarah.

462
00:17:47,400 --> 00:17:49,030
Have a wonderful concert.

463
00:17:49,030 --> 00:17:49,770
Thank you.

464
00:17:49,770 --> 00:17:51,960
See you, hopefully, all
again very, very soon.

465
00:17:51,960 --> 00:17:52,260
Thanks.

466
00:17:52,260 --> 00:17:52,860
Hope so, too.

467
00:17:52,860 --> 00:17:53,460
My pleasure.

468
00:17:53,460 --> 00:17:53,760
Thank you.

469
00:17:53,760 --> 00:17:55,010
Bye.

470
00:17:55,010 --> 00:17:55,920

metadata.title: 阿巴多、波利尼和普罗哈斯卡谈论新旧音乐友谊
metadata.description: 2011年5月，克劳迪奥·阿巴多与毛里奇奥·波利尼、安娜·普罗哈斯卡合作了一场音乐会。在这里，柏林爱乐乐团的圆号演奏员莎拉·维利斯与他们进行了一场对话。

concert.title: 克劳迪奥·阿巴多、毛里奇奥·波利尼与安娜·普罗哈斯卡
